2026-W02.narrative: This week I explored consistent hashing while designing a URL shortener, worked through graph algorithms like BFS and topological sort, and discovered that dragonflies have a 95% hunting success rate — the highest of any predator on Earth.

topics.name: graphs
topics.preview: BFS for shortest path, DFS for cycle detection

items.name: Number of Islands
items.insight: DFS flood fill to mark visited cells

items.name: Course Schedule
items.insight: Topological sort with cycle detection using colors

items.name: Clone Graph
items.insight: BFS with hashmap to track cloned nodes

items.name: Container With Most Water
items.insight: Two pointers shrink from both ends, move the shorter one

items.name: Trapping Rain Water
items.insight: Track max from left and right, water = min(maxL, maxR) - height

topics.name: bit.ly
topics.preview: Consistent hashing for distribution, base62 encoding for short URLs

items.name: bit.ly
items.insight: Consistent hashing for distribution, base62 encoding, read-heavy so cache aggressively

topics.name: DDIA
topics.preview: Replication lag patterns and eventual consistency trade-offs

items.insight: Replication lag causes read-your-writes issues, solutions include reading from leader for own writes
Multi-leader replication useful for multi-datacenter, but conflict resolution is hard

topics.name: dragonflies
topics.preview: 95% hunting success rate — the most efficient predator on Earth

items.content: Dragonflies have a 95% hunting success rate, making them the most efficient predators on Earth. They use predictive tracking, calculating where prey will be rather than chasing it.

topics.name: Journal pipeline
topics.preview: Topic extraction and weekly narrative generation

items.work: Built topic extraction system that groups LeetCode by algorithm
